title: How to Throw a 1940s Themed Party

steps.headline: Choose a party date with historical significance.
steps.description:
If you have flexibility, consider holding the party on a day that corresponds with an important event in history—like a significant military victory, the birthday of an important political figure, or the release of a Hollywood film. Selecting a historically significant date will help you incorporate the 1940s theme into decorations and activities. Consider:
The premier of the film Casablanca, November 26, 1942
Winston Churchill’s birthday, November 30. The end of war in Europe, May 8, 1945. The day Indonesia declared independence, August 17, 1945.

steps.headline: Find a venue that fits with your 1940s theme.
steps.description: Consider renting space at a historical location to reinforce your theme. If nearby venues don’t work, you can always hold the party in your own home. Just make sure that whatever space you select has enough room to host all of your guests. Old movie theatres, historic hotels, museums, or historic bars make great venues for a 1940s party. Try to find a location that was in operation during the 1940s, any site that feels historical and has enough space will work.

steps.headline: Send your guests invitations that reflect your theme.
steps.description: Invitations need to convey important information about location, time, date, and how to RSVP, but they should also help get your guests excited about your theme. To achieve this goal, create invitations that reflect the style and themes of the 1940s. Make sure to use the invitation to communicate special instructions to guests, such as instructions for dressing in 1940s style clothing. Make your invitations look like the front page of a historical newspaper by using the same style and font as a 1940s paper. Or consider using an old propaganda poster—like the iconic “I Want You” poster featuring Uncle Sam--and add your guests’ names to it. You can check online for templates! If you want your guests to dress in 1940s fashions, you can find old 1940s clothing catalogues online, print a few pages, and include them in your invitations. Or create a website with instructions and provide the link on your invitation. Don’t forget to include makeup and hair suggestions!

steps.headline: Park a historic car outside the entrance of your party.
steps.description: If you know someone with a historic car, ask them if you can borrow it. 1940s era vehicles are beautiful, and positioning a historic car outside your venue will set the theme right from the start.

steps.headline: Hang posters and photographs from the 1940s on the walls.
steps.description: There's a multitude of posters and iconic photographs from this era online. After searching for historic images, find a few that you’d like to enlarge and either print them yourself or visit a print shop to have them made professionally. Hang these posters on the venue walls or from the ceiling with string. Alternatively, have images printed on cardstock and prop them up against easels or furniture. Consider movie posters from 1940s films like: Casablanca, Citizen Kane, or Yankee Doodle Dandy. You can also print posters of iconic musicians like Bing Crosby or Frank Sinatra. Consider surrounding these posters with old records or musical instruments like horns. Natasha Miller			Event Planner & CEO, Entire Productions				Remember to include your decorations in your party budget. If you're going to decorate with props, florals, lighting, backdrops, and stagecraft, you have to have a budget carved out for that. Start by planning the most expensive costs, like your food and drinks. Then, look at what you have left over to make sure your design plan is really feasible.

steps.headline: Display patriotic decorations if you want a WWII theme.
steps.description: Hang flags as well as streamers with the countries' colors. Wartime propaganda posters also make good decorations. If you live in the United States, you can recycle Fourth of July decorations for your party. If you live in France, you might reuse Bastille Day decorations. Many propaganda posters are already popular and widely available such as the British “Keep Calm and Carry On” poster or the United States’ Rosie the Riveter images.

steps.headline: Set up a photo booth with period props.
steps.description: Photo booths have become mainstays of parties in recent years, and they are excellent ways to reinforce your party theme. Rent one from a party supply store, or make your own by setting up a space in the corner of your venue. You can either partition your DIY photo booth with curtains, or you can simply set up a backdrop with paper and decorations. The most important thing is to have instant cameras, like Polaroid’s, available. Also get props--like hats, purses, and gloves--which you can find in antique stores, thrift shops, or online.

steps.headline: Plan to play music from the 1940s.
steps.description: The 1940s were all about Big Band music, so consider hiring a band if you have the budget. Otherwise, hire or get a friend to DJ and have them play 1940s hits. Popular 1940s musicians and bands included: Benny Goodman, Glenn Miller, Tommy Dorsey, Duke Ellington, Bing Crosby, Ella Fitzgerald, Doris Day, and Frank Sinatra. If you can find a skilled DJ, ask them to try and mix audio clips from old radio broadcasts, films, or songs clips with contemporary music.

steps.headline: Set up a projector to feature historic video footage.
steps.description: Truly capture the 1940s with authentic footage from the time. Use clips from Hollywood movies, newsreels, and commercials. You can find a wealth of footage in the public domain from this period online—at sites like the UK's National Archive site, the Internet Archive, and even YouTube. Edit the footage to create a montage of 1940s clips to play on loop the day of your party. If you need help editing the film, search for online tutorials, ask a friend, or check out the media help desk at your nearest public library. On the day of your party, project the footage onto a wall or white sheet. Alternatively, you can use a large screen or television, but a projected video will appear grainier, so it'll have a more historic look. You probably want to set the footage on silent, so guests can converse with one another and enjoy other music or entertainment.

steps.headline: Serve drinks that were popular during the decade.
steps.description: Coca-Cola was all the rage during the time, so consider serving soda in classic, glass bottles for a non-alcoholic drink option. For delicious cocktails, serve traditional lime daiquiris, another popular choice during the period. If you're celebrating in the summer, hollow out a large watermelon and pour 2-3 cups of vodka inside to replicate a popular 1940s beach drink.

steps.headline: Make 1940s style party foods.
steps.description: Triangle shaped tortilla chips were invented during the 1940s, so serving chips and dip is a delicious way to highlight your theme. Consider preparing a spinach artichoke dip to go along with your chips since the cartoon Popeye popularized spinach during the time. Another way to incorporate some of your favorite appetizers into your theme is to pair them with a hot sauce since Tabasco sauce became popular in the 1940s. McDonald's opened its first restaurant in 1940, so it can be fun to serve hamburgers. Grilled shrimp or fried cheese sticks taste great with hot sauce.

steps.headline: Prepare food that reflects 1940s rationing rules.
steps.description: If you're throwing a WWII themed party, then you might want to research what food rationing policies were in place where you live. Most countries implemented strict rationing policies during the war. Chicken, for example, was hard to find in many countries, so avoid chicken dishes. And many cooks had to get creative with food substitutes when faced with shortages in butter, eggs, or even flour. In the Unites States, meat was rationed heavily, so cooks had to try and make organ meats like livers and hearts palatable to diners. If your guests are adventures eaters, consider making a liver pate or preparing something else with organ meat.

steps.headline: Serve desserts that were popular in the period.
steps.description: M&M candy was released in 1940, so serve M&Ms by themselves, offer them as a topping for ice cream, or decorate baked goods with them. Consider serving Jello since this dessert was a favorite of the period. Bake an eggless cake with margarine instead of butter in order to reflect 1940s style rationing rules.

steps.headline: Present your foods with thematic flourishes.
steps.description: Remind your party guests of the party theme when you showcase your creations. You can decorate a cake with a headline from a 1940s newspaper story. Or serve food in Tupperware, which was invented in 1946.

steps.headline: Greet everyone as they arrive.
steps.description: Stand near the door, so you can welcome your guests when they arrive. Incorporate your theme into this initial interaction. Hand guests a 1940s style cocktail or drink. You also might considering giving them a prop--like a 1940s style stick-on mustache or a pair of fake, plastic pearls.

steps.headline: Teach your guests a dance that was popular in the 1940s.
steps.description: Hire a dance instructor or recruit a talented friend to teach your guests how to dance like its the 1940s. The Jitterbug is a great dance to teach. If you’re really organized, you could even project footage of people dancing the Jitterbug in the 1940s, so your guests can dance along. Make sure to play a few songs that are compatible with the Jitterbug after your guests have learned it, so they can have fun with their new dance skills.

steps.headline: Hold a costume contest.
steps.description: Planning a costume contest is a great way to motivate your guests to dress up. It’s also an ideal way to weave your theme into the evening. Get everyone’s attention towards the end of the night or if you feel a lull in energy. Have guests take turns posing or walking a runway to show off their looks. Then have everyone write down the name of the person with the best costume on a piece of paper. Collect the votes, tally them up, and announce the winner. You could give the winner a gift like a vintage radio.

steps.headline: Give a period-specific toast.
steps.description: Make sure to give at least one brief toast at some point in the evening. In addition to toasting your friends, you can also make references to “our troops,” “our nation's independence,” or something else that’s specific to the 1940s. If you managed to hold your party on a historically specific date, this is a great chance to work those events into the evening. Consider giving this toast either at the beginning of the party to set the mood or towards the end to offer closure and thank everyone for coming.
